... slander [and] censure, [but] this does not stick to good people for long.
... (he will), together with the community, ermerge from the cloud of blame. [20d] For seven days all ...
... on all paths [21b] loudly proclaim the five strophes (of the) Buddha ... lie [as] truth certainly ...
... [21d], then the being speaking an unfounded thing here goes to hell. Also who ... in the (other) birth ... (both are indeed named the same:
two people of low kind. For in the mouth) of the man here born an axe (develops with which he cuts into his own flesh) when he says [slander]. (This second strophe spoke
the Omniscient) to keep the being away from evil: [22d] For who praises a reprehensible being, but blames those that are (praiseworthy) ... not suddenly ...
Wer nämlich ein tadelnswertes Wesen lobt, hingegen diejenigen tadelt, welche (lobenswert) [sind] ... (der findet) [so] bald nicht (Glück) in [seinen] Geburten.
For he who praises a blameworthy being, but, on the other hand, scolds those who [are] (praiseworthy) ... (he will) not [so] soon find (blessing) in [his] incarnations.
in [the] (births). Only [of] minor [relevance is] here the injury of a being, who loses (... [23d])
Nur gering [ist] hier dieser Verlust eines Wesens, das im Würfelspiel(?) verliert.
[It is] only a slight loss here, to a being that loses in a game of dice(?).

(reported all to him. The minister went and reported this) to the king in [its] breadth. (The king) summoned all Tīrthas ... (they told the truth to the king). [26d] (The king) ordered (to ban them from the whole country. It disappeared)
(Der König) beschied alle Tī(rthas) zu sich, ... sie sagten dem König die Wahrheit.
(The king) summoned all Tī(rthas) to him, ... they told the truth to the king.

(the cloud above the Śākya-sons, [and]) reverence for the Omniscient increased. Concerning this (he proclaimed the five strophes (before) the envious [ones] and the spiteful [ones], to restrain [their] mind and tongue). The one here speaks a lie without reason, (the second does a bad deed. Both)
(Der eine) spricht hier (un)begründet eine Lüge aus, der zwei(te tut böse Tat.) Beide werden in der Hölle [wieder-]geboren:

are [re]born in hell. In the first strophe you shall recognize this meaning: (The first by his lie is [re]born in hell, the second by his erring. [27d] A human) is certainly born (together)

This leaf immediately follows and and is the next but one after . It includes strophes 20b-28 and includes strophes 26-32, both of the Vācāvarga (VIII) in a 4x25 syllable–metre (rhythm 5/5/8/7). Thus both leaves are identical for strophes 26-28. The great gaps in strophe 20 – from the second line the beginning (11 syllables) is missing as is the entire line 3 – do not allow us to clearly see the connection to the following. However, verse Uv VIII 1, quoted in a4, is identical to Dhp 302, and the commentary to Dhp tells the story of the murder of the nun Sundarī, which was passed off by the Tīrthas as Buddha’s concubine and which they later had murdered in order to blame the killing on the Buddha and his community. Due to the king’s intervention, however, the real murderers are discovered and the Tīrthas are punished, while the reverence for the Buddha is even growing. For a translation and further references cf. , III: 189ff. The fact that also in our version this story is also associated with Uv VIII 1 is attested to by strophes 25ff., which apparently are dealing with the solving of the crime. The name Sundarī, too, seems to be preserved in the fragment.

div.p: correpsonds to Uv. 8, 1: abhūtavādī narakān upaiti yaś cānyad apy ācaratīha karma ubhau hi tau pretyasamau niruktau nihīnadharmau manujau paratra
He who affirms what is not, goes to hells; similarly, he who does something and denies it; both, once dead, will become the same below: they are men of base actions.
correpsonds to Uv. 8, 2: puruṣasya hi jātasya kuṭhārī jāyate mukhe yayā chinatti hātmānaṃ vācā durbhāṣitaṃ vadan
When a man is born, an axe grows in his mouth; he cuts himself with that axe when using wrong speech.
correpsonds to Uv. 8, 3: yo nindiyāṃ praśaṃsati tān api nindati ye praśaṃsiyāḥ sa cinoti mukhena taṃ kaliṃ kalinā tena sukhaṃ na vindati
He who praises whose who should be censured and censures those who are worthy of praise accumulates depravity; and that depravity prevents him from finding happiness.
correpsonds to Uv. 8, 4: alpa mātro hy ayaṃ kalir ya ihhākṣeṇa dhanaṃ parājayet ayam atra mahattaraḥ kalir yaḥ sugateṣu manaḥ pradūṣayet
Minor is the offence committed in this world by losing money at dice; greater here is the offence which corrupts the mind against Sugatas.
correpsonds to Uv. 8, 5: śataṃ sahasrāṇi nirarbudāni ṣaṭ triṃśatiṃ pañca tathārbudāni yān āryagarhī narakān upaiti vācaṃ manaś ca praṇidhāya pāpakam
To a hundred thousand Nirarbudas, and to five thousand and thirty-six Arbuda hells; that is where the men who reviles the good goes, having turned his speech and his mind towards wrong-doing.

General remarks

This leaf immediately follows [[THT 15]] and [[THT 18]] and is the next but one after [[THT 17]]. It includes strophes 20b-28 and [[THT 18]] includes strophes 26-32, both of the Vācāvarga (VIII) in a 4x25 syllable–metre (rhythm 5/5/8/7). Thus both leaves are identical for strophes 26-28. The great gaps in strophe 20 – from the second line the beginning (11 syllables) is missing as is the entire line 3 – do not allow us to clearly see the connection to the following. However, verse Uv VIII 1, quoted in a4, is identical to Dhp 302, and the commentary to Dhp tells the story of the murder of the nun Sundarī, which was passed off by the Tīrthas as Buddha’s concubine and which they later had murdered in order to blame the killing on the Buddha and his community. Due to the king’s intervention, however, the real murderers are discovered and the Tīrthas are punished, while the reverence for the Buddha is even growing. For a translation and further references cf. [[Burlingame 1921]], III: 189ff. The fact that also in our version this story is also associated with Uv VIII 1 is attested to by strophes 25ff., which apparently are dealing with the solving of the crime. The name Sundarī, too, seems to be preserved in the fragment.
